ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This course would benefit from either hydrology and biogeochemistry prerequisites or a more structured curriculum. As designed it benefited students who where advanced enough in these fields to accomplish a worthwhile project independently but greatly disadvantaged (and frustrated) those who weren't. While the team of professors had the potential to encourage collaboration across disciplines, the lack of foundational teaching within their respective disciplines only resulted in further division of the class and course.
Pace of class is hard to judge. As a project course the lecture material also seemed to range in three very different directions.

Things seemed a bit disorganized at first, but once we got our groups figured out I found the project-based set up of the course very helpful. I learned alot about my project focus; I came far in my knowledge base over the course of my semester. However, the knowledge gained was limited to my project (fine by me), did not retain much from the lectures/field trips in the earlier part of the semester if they did not relate to what I was working on.
There should have been more lectures. Three great professors were overseeing this course I think the students could have benefited more from their lectures.

This could be an amazing class- but instead it is the worst class I've taken at Yale. The professors, particularly prof. Saiers, really don't care at all. They barely teach (Benoit and Raymond did teach a few classes each), but Saiers just had his phd students give worthless lectures. This class is an embarrassment to Yale.

I really enjoyed this course; however I know that it received mixed reviews. The class is what you make of it. Providedyou have a good project and actively engage your adviser, you can take a lot away from this class.

I thought the course should have spent a LOT more time focusing on using class time to brainstorm aroundthe design challenges and work with the professors during that time. The lectures didn't really feel applicable to the project I was doing and felt unnecessary.

Q2: The work is entirely out-of-class, but the class is not billed as such an intense project-based course. Q5-7: Field trips did not apply / were not of interest to everyone, due to the project-based nature the course took on. Q8-10: The instructors disappointed us. There was so much potential to learn from the combined expertise of three of them, but they didn't coordinate the structure of the class well, or how their respective lectures would dovetail. Lectures were too few; my learning from the class was entirely from what I taught myself for my group's project. I learned next to nothing from in-class time, which made going to class seem like a waste. Q12: students interested in watershed cycles and processes would do well to look elsewhere unless they want a jump-start on a pretty intense project which could become (or give them experience for) their master's (MESc or MFS) research project.

Class was unstructured and unhelpful. Instructors threw together lectures last minute (when they actually gave them - most of the class was basically an independent study). Class had great potential but ended up being a waste of time.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Project and experimental work.
The projects.
The few good lectures from Raymond and Benoit.
Freedom to choose what project to pursue.
The opportunity to choose a project of interest and work with students from a variety of skill sets wasextremely valuable. I learned a lot from my teammates.
Learned a lot about new field and lab techniques.
I had a great group to work with and we had a lot of fun working together on the final project.
Semester long independent study project.
Developing my own project and doing real science.
One-on-one help from one of the instructors. However, this was somewhat difficult and stressful to coordinate with group-work and multiple people's schedules.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Curriculum.
Lectures. Project setup.
It would be helpful to have a more streamlined process for selecting groups/research questions so that we could get working on our projects sooner.
More lectures
The course could be better structured/organized. I rarely knew what we were discussing in class before arriving to the classroom. Some of the lectures were not too helpful.

This really isn't a class. It's an excuse for 3 good professors to knock out their teaching load while doing no work. It's pathetic that the 3 water professors at Yale together teach one class, that doesn't meet for most of the semester, has no assigned readings, and isn't even well organized.
Better organization and vision for the goals of the course.

The team projects could have been better supported by readings throughout the semester. It was difficult to build on knowledge from week to week and understand course requirements without a finalized syllabus/schedule of lecture topics.
More robust lecture schedule would be helpful.
The lectures.

Though the course was designed to support independent projects Iwould have appreciated a syllabus with lecture topics and when (or generally when) they would be offered. I understand the professors would like to maintain flexibility to be able to address topics of interest as they arise but it hard for me to contextualize information presented outside of the independent project.

Lack of guidance from instructors. We should have had more structured meetings and updates. I really felt like I was out on my own teaching myself material to complete the project and spent undue time on it.

Coordination amongst the instructors, and legitimate course content. It was unfair to be so demanding with us regarding each of our projects, but not hold themselves to the same standards regarding course content and student learning. It at times seemed like the course was being run as a data-collection factory with free labor from Master's students.
More guidance from the professors on projects would be very helpful.
Lectures need to be given in reference to the course title: Watershed Cycles and Processes. Everything learned in the class was done so outside of class hours.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: See Question 13 response. Field investigations should be more engaging and reinforce lectures.
Could be improved

I found that omly some lectures were applicable to our project, which is expected given that people were working in different topics. However, a workshop type class instead of a lecture on Matlab, for example, would have been more useful. It's hard to learn the basics of a computer program by watching someone else use it.
The few walks we had to the swale had no apparent connection to what was done in class.
Lots of great labs and out of class assignments; in-class discussions didn't always relate directly to all projects, given the varied nature off all of the groups projects.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Invaluable. Would have been good to have taken hydrology before this course.
I was able to work on a project that fits into my overall program. And it helped build a lot of knowledge.
It should have been an ideal fit- however I didn't get much of anything out of it. I learned more during the final presentations from the other groups than I did during the entire semester of class.
I got really lucky on the design challenge and that allowed me the chance to work on skills that I wanted to continue to develop.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Part of curriculum.
It is relevant to my course of study
I wanted to learn more about watershed science and management.
To learn more about watersheds
It should have been an excellent fit for anyone interested in water. The course description was good, but had no connection to the actual course content.
To continue taking the water-based curriculum at FES.
I wanted the opportunity to deepen my knowledge of watershed processes and work on a research-oriented project.
Interested in the topic material.
For the ability to work on developing my innovation skills.
I wanted to take a science based water course this semester and this was one of the few that were offered.
Because I am interested in watersheds. However, I learned nothing about watersheds.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes

It did - my project was relevant to my specific area of interest. It's a project course, so if you like your project you'll get a lot out of the course. If your project is not a good fit from your interest, the course will not teach you much of interest.
I think there could have been more lectures.
No- not at all.
No, I was hoping to learn more technical skills.
I learned a lot during the course of the research project. However, I ended the semester feeling like I didnât have a strong command of the broader hydrology literature outside of my own project.
Yes
Somewhat but it was largely because of the group I was with. I could see that I wouldn't have gotten as much out of the class with a different group.
I certainly learned new lab and research skills. By the end of the course I wish I would have focused more on hydrologic modeling.
I learned alot- but taught every thing myself. There was little teaching in this course.
Not from the class per se; rather, from my own learning for the course project.
No - I ended up with very little from the class, outside of my own pursuits.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantages - Multiple perspectives and problem solving abilities. Negative - equal sharing of the work, sometimes not the best approach. For example, powerpoint slide coordination or final paper write up.
Sharing the workload was critical.
Working in a group was really helpful given the amount of work we had to do for the class.
I worked with a great group- however the faculty support was terrible. In fact, the professors seemed actively unhelpful and did not give clear direction at all.
I felt like I did the lion's share of the work. My partner was disinterested in the course and therefore the project.

The groups allowed us to bring together different skill sets and areas of expertise in order to pursue stronger projects. My group actively worked to improve communication over the course of the semester.
Very committed group members. We all learned a lot.
I had a fantastic group.
My group worked well together.
Range of skillsets from different group members.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Only take it if you have already covered basic hydrology and biogeochemistry.
Hydrology or other prereqs would have made the first month or two much easier.
Make sure you have an idea of what you want to research, and how, before starting this course.

Take this class if you have a project you are excited about (if you don't have an idea off the bat that's okay, there will be suggested topics). You spend most of your time working on your project (most of the semester you don't have lecture, just meetings with your group/adviser, so it's not a survey class or lecture class.
Take advantage of all three professors.
Don't take it- terrible class. Unless they split out and teach individually, I would never take another class from these 3 professors.

If you have a project in mindor a specific skill set (especially related to hydrological modeling) that you would like to develop, then this is a good course. However, there is currently a lack of supportive background material and developed lecture schedule to support student work. Follow up with professors is key to learning in this type of class.
See above advice.
Seek out a design challengethat you're excited about because you'll spend a lot of time thinking about it.
Have a clear vision of what skills you would like to get out of the course from the outset and pick a project that would allow you to learn/refine those skills.
Only take this if you have a specific project you want to work on and need a class slot to fill it. the Instruction here is minimal.
Take this course only if the instructors majorly overhaul how it is being taught, or if you can work on your research project as the course project (which I believe they prohibited this year).
This is very much a project course. Most time will be focused on project work.
